#: by Elliotte Harold's words the mind was *winged* :#
> Alexandru Popescu wrote:
> 
>> [quote]
>> An assertion is a statement in the JavaTM programming language that enables you to test your 
>> assumptions about your program.
>> [/quote]
> 
> Java assertions inside the code are a very different thing from external 
> test cases. The word "assert" and "test" are both getting overloaded 
> here. Such is the imprecision of English. This is similar to the problem 
> introduced in Java 1.4 where Sun decided to start using the word assert 
> in a way that broke pretty much every test suite on the planet.
> 
> An AssertionError means that somewhere in the Java code there's an 
> assert statement that failed, not that a JUnit assertMethod failed. It 
> means that the stack trace will point right to the line that failed. It 
> means that the detail message is precisely defined according to the type 
> of assertion that failed, and the string conversion of the expressions 
> as defined in section 15.18.1.1 of the Java Language Specification. It 
> has a whole bunch of behavior and semantics tied up in this notion that 
> just don't apply when it's caused by a JUnit test failure.
> 
> 
Unfortunately, I cannot follow you :-(. Reading the AssertionError API:

[quote]
Thrown to indicate that an assertion has failed.
[/quote]

While testing we are almost always talking about assertion. I agree that using an Error, instead of 
an exception may be just a little wrong.
I am not sure what do you mean by <<right to the line that failed>>. Any Throwable will do just the 
same.
As about the string conversion, that is only defining how a string conversion takes place, so i 
cannot see any relation to assertion.

This is beginning to sound religious, so maybe it would be better to agree to disagree :-).

:alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
